Adam Fisk wrote:
> I'm trying to use SurtPrefixedDecideRule to run a relatively simple
> crawl.  Here's the XML from my order file:
> 
> <newObject
> class="org.archive.crawler.deciderules.SurtPrefixedDecideRule"
> name="acceptIfSurtPrefixed">
>   <string name="decision">ACCEPT</string>
>   <string name="surts-source-file"/>
>   <boolean name="seeds-as-surt-prefixes">true</boolean>
>   <string name="surts-dump-file"/>
> </newObject>
> 
> In my understanding, I can then just use SURT prefixes in my seeds
> file.  My seeds file contains the following:
> 
> +http://(org,example,
> 
> When I run this, though, I get the log warning below when it's
> processng the seeds file, apparently indicating it's not expecting a
> SURT here.  Should I just specify http://example.org in the seeds,
> allowing it to derive the SURT above?  Or maybe I should use an
> external SURT file?   

The warning is harmless, generated when scanning the seeds for plain
URLs. Specifying the SURT inline with the "+" notation generates the
warning but also should ahve the desired effect. Though, it's always
a good idea to verify this by using the 'surt-dump-file' to see the
SURT prefixes actually in use after all sources are consulted.

As you found, an external SURT file will also work well.

If you just specify "http://example.org" in the seeds, and have 'seeds
as surts' checked, the right SURT prefix will be established -- but
"http://example.org" will also be visited, which may not be what you
want.

- Gordon @ IA
